title: 109_s3825
content: The Act may be cited as the "Methamphetamine Trafficking Prevention Act of 2006". The Methamphetamine Trafficking Prevention Act of 2006 aims to curb domestic methamphetamine production by addressing the international stream of commerce for precursors. Successful exchange programs between the DEA and Mexican law enforcement have aided in limiting methamphetamine production in Mexico. The goal of US policy is to reduce methamphetamine abuse and manufacture. The Methamphetamine Trafficking Prevention Act of 2006 aims to reduce domestic methamphetamine production by targeting international precursor trafficking. The Act includes the Border Technology Grants Program, allowing grants for technology and aerial surveillance to detect methamphetamine and its precursors at the US border. States and eligible private entities can apply for grants by demonstrating project viability. The Border Technology Grants Program allows eligible private entities to apply for grants to use technology or aerial surveillance to detect methamphetamine and its precursors at the US border. The program considers technologies that can detect active methamphetamine production sites through the use of hyperspectral sensors. Eligible private entities are defined as those using technology to identify methamphetamine or its precursors. The Border Technology Grants Program authorizes $15,000,000 for fiscal years 2007 through 2011 to deploy trace chemical detectors along the US border to detect narcotics and explosive devices. SEC. 4. COORDINATION OF ANTI-METHAMPHETAMINE ACTIVITIES WITH OTHER COUNTRIES. The United States Trade Representative should address illicit use of pseudoephedrine and ephedrine in trade negotiations. The Drug Enforcement Administration will involve foreign law enforcement officers in a special investigative program, focusing on countries trafficking methamphetamine or its precursors into the United States.
